{{Multiple issues| {{primary sources|date=October 2009}} {{advert|date=October 2009}} {{Update|the New Jersey Department of Banking and Insurance's assessment of company performance in 2008|date=November 2014}} {{Orphan|date=January 2015}} }}
{{Infobox company | name = [[AmeriHealth New Jersey]] | logo = https://www.amerihealthnj.com/Resources/images/logos/ANHJ_rgb_logo_ps.svg | type = [[Subsidiary]] | key_people = Mike Sullivan - President & Senior Vice President of Diversified Businesses for Independence Blue Cross
Mike Munoz - Senior Vice President of Sales & Marketing
Ken Kobylowski - Senior Vice President of Provider Contracting & Network Operations | industry = [[Insurance]] | products = [[Health insurance]] | num_employees =200 | parent = [[Independence Blue Cross]] | homepage = [[www.amerihealthnj.com]] | foundation = 1995 | location = [[Cranbury, New Jersey]] | }}
'''AmeriHealth New Jersey''' is a provider of [[health insurance]] to nearly 260,000 employers and individuals throughout [[New Jersey]]. The company's contracted hospital and physician network includes thousands of physicians at 76 hospitals throughout its service area.<ref>[http://www.amerihealth.com/news_events/press_releases/2009/07_01_Amerihealth_New_Jersey_B.html Network Update], amerihealth.com</ref> Its [[HMO]] and [[Point of service plan|POS]] plans are New Jersey's top-rated health plans based on the highest ratings for customer service and quality-of-care in the 2008 New Jersey Department of Banking and Insurance HMO Performance Report.<ref>[http://www.nj.gov/dobi/lifehealthactuarial/hmo2008/performancesummary.html 2008 NJDOBI Performance Report], nj.gov</ref> AmeriHealth New Jersey is headquartered in [[Cranbury, New Jersey|Cranbury]].
AmeriHealth New Jersey offers nationwide coverage through PHCS, a [[Preferred Provider Organization]] (PPO). The company offers insurance solutions through AmeriHealth’s wellness benefits and incentive programs.<ref>[http://www.amerihealth.com/providers/communications/news/2008_09_25_national_access_program.html AmeriHealth News: National Access], amerihealth.com</ref>
==History== AmeriHealth, originally known as Delaware Valley HMO, was established in 1995 to provide health coverage to [[Pennsylvania]] employers and their staff residing in [[Burlington County, New Jersey|Burlington]], [[Camden County, New Jersey|Camden]], [[Gloucester County, New Jersey|Gloucester]], and [[Salem County, New Jersey|Salem]] counties of New Jersey. It expanded its coverage area to include southern New Jersey and [[Delaware]], and, by 1997, AmeriHealth offered coverage to the entire state of New Jersey.<ref>[http://www.amerihealth.com/about/company_information/company_history.html AmeriHealth History], amerihealth.com</ref> In 2013 AmeriHealth announced it would be offering plans in New Jersey on the federally run [[Health insurance marketplace|health insurance exchange]].<ref>https://finance.yahoo.com/news/amerihealth-jersey-cooper-university-health-163100916.html</ref>
== Wellness programs == AmeriHealth New Jersey is a provider of employer on-site [[health coaching]] with a nurse wellness specialist to small- and mid-sized New Jersey-based organizations. [[Workplace wellness]] services include sending registered nurses to provide a broad spectrum of on-site health education, seminars, screenings, and support. AmeriHealth New Jersey offers an [[incentive]]-based wellness program,<ref>[http://www.amerihealth.com/members/health_resources/index.html AmeriHealth, Health Resources], amerihealth.com</ref> called Commit2Wellness Rewards, which provides individuals and groups with tools to support wellness and rewards for living a healthy lifestyle.
==Community involvement== AmeriHealth New Jersey is the name sponsor of the [[New Jersey Devils]]’ practice facility, the AmeriHealth Pavilion. At the time this sponsorship was announced, news reports cited AmeriHealth’s desire to contribute to the “revitalization of Newark.”<ref>[http://www.nj.com/devils/index.ssf/2008/09/devils_practice_facility_now_h.html AmeriHealth contributing to the revitalization of downtown Newark], by Rich Chere, 2 September 2008, ''[[The Star-Ledger]]''</ref>
AmeriHealth New Jersey is also a sponsor and participant in [[Special Olympics]] New Jersey’s annual “[[Lincoln Tunnel]] Challenge.” In 2009 the event drew a record crowd of 3,500 runners and walkers to the tunnel. Additionally, AmeriHealth New Jersey sponsors and participates in the “[[Ben Franklin Bridge]] Challenge,” which benefits the Larc School for the disabled;<ref>[http://www.runthebridge.org/Sponsors/2008_Sponsors.html Ben Franklin Bridge Challenge], Larc School</ref><ref>[http://www.redorbit.com/news/health/674356/amerihealth_ben_franklin_bridge_challenge_to_attract_3000_participants/index.html Red Orbit News - Ben Franklin Bridge Challenge], PRNewswire</ref> and sponsors [[Rutgers University]] and several local the minor league baseball teams.<ref>[http://www.riversharks.com/sponsors/partnershipslist.cfm Camden Riversharks Sponsorship] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090525024356/http://www.riversharks.com/sponsors/partnershipslist.cfm |date=2009-05-25 }}, Camden Riversharks</ref>
== Awards and recognition == [[New Jersey Business and Industry Association|NJBIZ]] magazine has recognized AmeriHealth New Jersey in multiple awards programs over the past several years. The company is one of [http://www.njbiz.com/article/20160218/NJBIZ01/160219803/these-are-njs-best-places-to-work-for-2016?utm_camp New Jersey's Best Places to Work] for five consecutive years, one of the [http://www.njbiz.com/article/20150826/NJBIZ01/150829860 Top Privately Held Companies], and one of the [http://www.njbiz.com/section/50-Fast-Grow-Comp 50 Fastest Growing Companies in New Jersey].
<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.njbiz.com/article/20160218/NJBIZ01/160219803/these-are-njs-best-places-to-work-for-2016|title=These are N.J.'s Best Places to Work for 2016 {{!}} NJBIZ|website=NJBIZ|access-date=2016-05-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.njbiz.com/section/50-Fast-Grow-Comp|title=50 Fastest Growing Companies {{!}} NJBIZ|website=NJBIZ|access-date=2016-05-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.njbiz.com/article/20150826/NJBIZ01/150829860|title=Top 100 Privately Held Companies, Nos. 50-1 {{!}} NJBIZ|website=NJBIZ|access-date=2016-05-11}}</ref>
AmeriHealth earned top ratings for customer service and quality of care in the 2008 New Jersey Department of Banking and Insurance’s HMO Performance Report.<ref>[http://www.state.nj.us/dobi/lifehealthactuarial/hmo2008/index.html 2008 State of New Jersey Department of Banking and Insurance HMO Report Card]</ref>
The company’s managed care plan, AmeriHealth HMO Inc. of New Jersey, has received the highest possible accreditation by the [[National Committee for Quality Assurance]] (NCQA) by meeting NCQA's rigorous evaluation standards.<ref>[http://www.ncqa.org/tabid/566/Default.aspx NCQA Health Care Quality Report] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081011193559/http://www.ncqa.org/tabid/566/Default.aspx |date=2008-10-11 }}, [[National Committee for Quality Assurance]]</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [http://www.AmeriHealthnj.com AmeriHealth New Jersey Website]
[[Category:Companies based in Middlesex County, New Jersey]] [[Category:Companies established in 1995]] [[Category:Health maintenance organizations]] [[Category:Insurance companies of the United States]] [[Category:Mount Laurel, New Jersey]] [[Category:Woodbridge Township, New Jersey]] [[Category:Health insurance companies]] [[Category:Health care companies based in New Jersey]]

{{update|date=July 2017}} {{Infobox lake |name = Boskov Most |image = |caption = |image_bathymetry = |caption_bathymetry = |location = Boskov Most, Macedonia |coords = {{coord|41|33|5.45|N|20|36|52.48|E|type:waterbody_scale:1000_region:MK|display=inline,title}} |type = [[reservoir]] |inflow = |outflow = |catchment = |basin_countries = [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]] |length = |width = |area = |depth = |max-depth = |volume = |residence_time = |shore = |elevation = |islands = |cities = }} '''Boškov Most Hydro Power Plant''', hereinafter referred to as Boškov Most HPP, is planned to be built in Mala Reka valley in the southernmost part of the [[Mavrovo National Park]]. It will have a total capacity of 70 MW.<ref name="balkanrivers">{{cite web |url=http://www.balkanrivers.net/en/key-areas/mavrovo-national-park | title=Dam construction plans put national park at risk | work=Save the blue heart of Europe | accessdate=20 August 2014}}</ref> The project threatens the survival of the [[Balkan lynx]].<ref name="bankwatch">[http://bankwatch.org/sites/default/files/briefing-BoskovMost-6May2014.pdf The hydropower plant Boskov Most.] ''CEE Bankwatch''. May 2014, Retrieved 20 August 2014.</ref> The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development ([[EBRD]]) agreed in November 2011 to lend EUR 65 million to [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]] for the construction of the [[dam]].<ref name="ebrd">{{cite web |url=http://www.ebrd.com/pages/project/psd/2011/41979.shtml |title=Project summary - Boskov Most hydro power project |accessdate=20 August 201 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111113234244/http://www.ebrd.com/pages/project/psd/2011/41979.shtml |archivedate=2011-11-13 |df= }}</ref>
==General information== Boškov Most HPP will be built near the town of [[Debar]] in the western part of the country and will have a generating capacity of 70 MW.<ref name="power">{{cite web | url=http://www.power-technology.com/news/newsebrd-to-provide-finance-for-hydro-power-plant-in-macedonia | title=EBRD to provide finance for hydro power plant in Macedonia. | work=Power-technology.com | date=14 November 2011 | accessdate=20 August 2014}}{{Unreliable source?|reason=domain on WP:BLACKLIST|date=June 2016}}</ref> It is intended to utilise the [[hydro power]] potential of the [[Tributary|tributaries]] of the river Mala Reka and will include a dam and a [[reservoir]] near the [[village]] of [[Tresonče|Tresonce]].<ref name="ebrd"/> It is estimated that it will produce 117 GW of power per year.<ref name="water">{{cite web | url=http://www.waterpowermagazine.com/news/newsloan-agreed-for-boskov-most-project-macedonia | title=Loan agreed for Boskov Most project, Macedonia. |work=Water Power & Dam Construction | date=14 November 2011 | accessdate=20 August 2014}}</ref> Plans to build the Boskov Most HPP date back to 1983 but it was postponed several times due to financial problems.<ref name="balkaninsight">{{cite web | last1=Marusic | first1=Sinisa Jakov |url=http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/article/macedonia-launches-hydro-power-plant-project | title=Macedonia Signs Deal to Build Hydro Power Plant |work=Balkan insight |date=11 November 2011 | accessdate=20 August 2014}}</ref>
In November 2011 European Bank for Reconstruction and Development ([[EBRD]]) signed on loaning a country EUR 65 million for the construction of the project.<ref name="ebrd"/> The rest is to be provided by the AD Elektrani na Makedonija (ELEM).<ref name="balkaninsight"/>
ELEM is a 100% [[State ownership|state owned]] electric power utility of Macedonia responsible for [[mining]] and power generation. It was formed in 2005 and currently carries out mining operations in four [[coal mine]]s and operates 1,329 MW of power generating capacity, of which 60% is [[Lignite fired power plant|lignite-fired]] and 40% [[hydropower]].<ref name="ebrd"/>
In 2011 it was estimated that the total cost of the project was to be EUR 84 million however,<ref name="ebrd"/> in 2014 that figure rose to EUR 107 million.<ref name="bankwatch"/>
==The importance of the project for the Macedonian energy sector== Unfavourable [[energy mix]], strong [[Energy dependence|dependence on energy]] import, obsolete [[Electric power system|energy system]] and inefficiency in energy production and use are the main problems of the Macedonian energy sector.<ref name="elsevier">{{cite web |last1=Ćosić | first1=Boris | first2=Goran | last2=Krajačić |first3=Neven | last3=Duić. |url=http://powerlab.fsb.hr/Neven/pdf/A-100-renewable-energy-system-in-the-year-2050-The-case-of-Macedonia.pdf | title=A 100% renewable energy system in the year 2050: The case of Macedonia. |work=Elsevier | date=29 June 2012 | accessdate=20 August 2014}}</ref> Macedonia [[import]]s roughly a quarter of its annual electricity needs.<ref name="balkaninsight"/> Domestic energy production is based mainly on the low-quality domestic [[lignite]], [[Biomass energy|biomass]] and [[Hydroelectricity|hydro]].<ref name="elsevier"/> The purpose of the Boškov most HPP is to support Macedonia's drive to improve the security and quality of its energy supplies, as well as promoting [[renewable sources]] of energy generation. Once operating, the plant will enable the nation to reduce electricity imports and in addition decrease the [[carbon intensity]] of the Macedonian generation sector.<ref name="ebrd"/><ref name="power"/>
==Controversial issues==
===Environmental impact===
The [[Mavrovo National Park]] is one of the oldest national parks in [[Europe]], famous for its pristine nature. The park hosts more than 1,000 different plant species. [[Trout]] species, [[Wolf|wolves]], [[bear]]s and [[otter]]s are an important part of the [[ecosystem]]. The park is also a centre of the remaining population of the [[Balkan lynx|Balkan Lynx]], an endangered subspecies of the [[Eurasian lynx|Eurasian Lynx]].<ref name="balkanrivers"/> The territory where it moves is thus a [[critical habitat]] and represents an area where measures for protection and preservation of this species should be undertaken.<ref name="bankwatch"/> Putting any additional stress on this source population may lead to the [[extinction]] of the species.<ref name="balkanrivers"/>
Boškov HPP is designed to produce peak energy which means that the water from Mala Reka river and its [[Tributary|tributaries]] will be diverted into a [[reservoir]] and on demand released once a day. Aside from the fact that the entire valley will suffer from the diversion of the majority of its natural water supplies, it will also result in daily flushes, which have enormous negative impacts on [[biodiversity]] and species populations in the river sections below the HPP.<ref name="bankwatch"/>
===Legal issues===
The [[Environmental impact assessment]] prepared for the project is lacking significant information vital for the precise and objective evaluation of the impact of the project on the environment, specifically data on the [[mammal]]s in the project area and complete absence of the [[Balkan lynx]] from the study.<ref name="bankwatch"/>
The project is also not in accordance with Law on Nature protection specifically with Article 74, which does not envisage the use of [[natural resource]]s for energy as a part of [[national park]] management and Article 75 which lists the prohibited activities in the national park. Furthermore, the project is not in accordance with the following [[international convention]]s signed and ratified by the government of Macedonia: [[Bern Convention (conservation)|Bern Convention]], [[Bonn Convention]] and [[Convention on Biological Diversity|Convention on Biodiversity]].<ref name="bankwatch"/>
===Cancellation of the Project===
After over five years of campaigns against the Boskov Most project, CEE Bankwatch along with its member groups, Macedonian center for environmental research and information, Eko-svest, and Macedonian environmental lawyer association, Front 21/42, finally welcomed the cancellation of the project. <ref>https://bankwatch.org/press_release/destructive-hydropower-project-in-macedonia-loses-its-only-source-of-funding</ref> In 2015, just few days after the [[Berne Convention on the Conservation of European Wildlife and Natural Habitats|Berne Convention]] decision on [[Mavrovo National Park|Mavrovo]], the [[World Bank]] withdrew its funds from the Lukovo Pole project, thus preventing the project from being realised. It took the [[EBRD]] another year to cancel its EUR 65 million loan<ref>https://bankwatch.org/press_release/macedonia-urged-to-suspend-controversial-hydropower-project</ref> for Boškov Most as well, stating that it fully respects Bern Convention’s recommendation and believes that the project should be suspended.<ref>https://bankwatch.org/press_release/destructive-hydropower-project-in-macedonia-loses-its-only-source-of-funding</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{stack|{{Portal|Republic of Macedonia|Water|Renewable energy}}}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090529195029/http://www.elem.com.mk/images/photo/projects/Boshkov_Most.pdf Boskov Most Hydro Power Plant] *[http://bankwatch.org/sites/default/files/briefing-BoskovMost-6May2014.pdf The hydropower plant Boskov Most]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Boskov Most Hydro Power Plant}} [[Category:Hydroelectric power stations in the Republic of Macedonia]] [[Category:Proposed hydroelectric power stations]] [[Category:Dams in the Republic of Macedonia]] [[Category:Mavrovo and Rostuša Municipality]]

revision.text:
{{Redirect|Chainsmoker|the EDM producers|The Chainsmokers}}
'''Chain smoking''' is the practice of smoking several [[cigarette]]s in succession, sometimes using the ember of a finished cigarette to light the next. The term '''chain smoker''' often also refers to a person who [[tobacco smoking|smokes]] relatively constantly, though not necessarily ''chaining'' each cigarette. The term applies primarily to cigarettes, although it can be used to describe incessant cigar and pipe smoking as well. It is a common form of [[Substance dependence|addiction]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Charles |first=Gerras |title=The Encyclopedia of Common Diseases|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=U7NZwYhrBWIC|page=17 |year=1976 |publisher=Rodale Press |isbn=978-0-87857-113-0}}</ref>
==Causes== The use of [[cocaine]] or an [[amphetamine]] with cigarettes can result in chain smoking.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Fisher |first1=Gary L. |last2=Roget |first2=Nancy A. |title=Encyclopedia of Substance Abuse Prevention, Treatment, and Recovery |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wPJ-39gVHE0C |date=11 November 2008 |publisher=SAGE Publications |isbn=978-1-4129-5084-8 }}</ref> Many people chain-smoke when drinking [[Alcoholic drink|alcoholic beverage]]s, because [[ethanol|alcohol]] potentiates [[nicotinic acetylcholine receptor]]s, leading to [[Reverse tolerance|re-sensitization]] and hence inducing a craving.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1080/14622200310001656957 |url=http://ntr.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/reprint/6/1/133.pdf |title=Psychopharmacological interactions between nicotine and ethanol |last1=Rose |first1=J. |last2=Brauer |first2=L. |last3=Behm |first3=F. |last4=Cramblett |first4=M. |journal=Nicotine & Tobacco Research |year=2004 |volume=6 |issue=1 |pages=133–44 |pmid=14982697}}</ref>
The extent to which chain smoking is driven by [[nicotine dependence]] has been studied. It does not seem that the amount of nicotine delivered is a significant factor, as the puff volume correlates poorly with the frequency of cigarette consumption.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/0091-3057(92)90535-N |title=Effects of smoking abstinence and chain-smoking on puffing topography and diurnal nicotine exposure |last1=Kolonen |first1=S. |last2=Tuomisto |first2=J. |last3=Puustinen |first3=P. |last4=Airaksinen |first4=M. M. |journal=[[Pharmacol Biochem Behav]] |year=1992 |volume=42 |pages=327–32 |issue=2 |pmid=1631188}}</ref>
==Clinical use== Chain-smoking is given as an example of excessive [[Substance dependence|addictive behaviour]] in the [[Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Helen |first=Keane |title=What's Wrong with Addiction? |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QqZsDnXS3-cC |date=2002 |page=100 |publisher=Melbourne University Publish |isbn=978-0-522-84991-2}}</ref> It may be used as a form of [[aversion therapy]] for smokers who are unused to such heavy smoking, inducing them to give up altogether.<ref>{{cite book |last=Cocores |first=James |title=The Clinical Management of Nicotine Dependence |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=f-lrAAAAMAAJ |date=1991 |publisher=Springer-Verlag |isbn=978-0-387-97464-4 }}</ref>
==Ventilation== Heating, ventilating, and air conditioning ([[HVAC]]) professionals claim that an airflow of about 1000 cubic feet (28.32 cubic meters) per minute per smoker is required to maintain satisfactory air quality when the smokers are chain smoking.<ref>{{cite book |last=Rock |first=Brian A. |title=Ventilation for Environmental Tobacco Smoke |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PDupTtFRClkC |date=13 January 2006 |publisher=Elsevier Science |isbn=978-0-08-052539-6|page=48 }}</ref> However, research confirms that current HVAC systems, while important for general air quality, cannot control exposure to [[Passive smoking|secondhand smoke]].<ref>{{cite book |url=http://www.surgeongeneral.gov/library/secondhandsmoke/report/fullreport.pdf |page=92 |title=The Health Consequences of Involuntary Exposure to Tobacco Smoke: A Report of the Surgeon General |author=U.S. Department of Health and Human Services |year=2006 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090205173605/http://www.surgeongeneral.gov/library/secondhandsmoke/report/fullreport.pdf |archivedate=2009-02-05 |df= }}</ref>
==Chain smokers== {{Cleanup list|section|date=March 2015}} <!-- WARNING Please do not insert unreferenced text, especially about real persons. This is against major Wikipedia policies --> <!--- name of chain smokers to be added after they die, & with proper references? --> A number of public figures were noted for being chain smokers.
{{columns-list|colwidth=20em| * [[Dick Allen]]<ref>{{cite news|last=King|first=Kelley|title=Dick Allen, Baseball Bad Boy|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1016417/index.htm|access-date=27 October 2013|newspaper=Sports Illustrated|date=19 July 1999|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029195238/http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1016417/index.htm|archivedate=29 October 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> * [[Mark Belanger]]<ref name="Okrent">{{cite book|last=Okrent|first=Daniel|title=Nine Innings: The Anatomy of a Baseball Game|year=1985|publisher=Houghton Mifflin Company|location=New York|isbn=0-618-05669-6|page=107|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UnsF1bdNw5AC&pg=PT124&lpg=PT124&dq=%22mark+belanger%22+chain+smoker&source=bl&ots=C8ClloMteI&sig=loGhLHJehaBgL4YsND_iXZmTIoQ&hl=en&sa=X&ei=MJ1sUrXFJoqU2wWC8ICwCw&ved=0CE8Q6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=%22mark%20belanger%22%20chain%20smoker&f=false|authorlink=Daniel Okrent}}</ref> * [[John Boehner]]<ref>{{cite news|last=DeFrank|first=Thomas M.|title='Face the Nation' cigarette query rattles chain-smokin' GOP big John Boehner|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/face-nation-cigarette-query-rattles-chain-smokin-gop-big-john-boehner-article-1.4431738|access-date=27 October 2013|newspaper=New York Daily News|date=13 September 2010}}{{Dead link|date=August 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * [[Bear Bryant|Paul "Bear" Bryant]]<ref>{{cite web|last=Thompson|first=Wright|title=The last ride of Bear and Billy|url=http://espn.go.com/espn/otl/story/_/id/7956658/thirty-years-bear-bryant-final-season-man-knew-best-billy-varner-struggles-remember-legendary-alabama-coach|work=ESPN.com|access-date=27 October 2013|date=24 May 2012|authorlink=Wright Thompson|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029223531/http://espn.go.com/espn/otl/story/_/id/7956658/thirty-years-bear-bryant-final-season-man-knew-best-billy-varner-struggles-remember-legendary-alabama-coach|archivedate=29 October 2013|df=}}</ref> * [[Gustavo Cerati]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.esplota.com/algunas-curiosidades-sobre-el-siempre-recordado-gustavo-cerati/|title=Algunas curiosidades sobre el siempre recordado Gustavo Cerati|author=|date=|website=www.esplota.com|accessdate=1 May 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180128132834/https://www.esplota.com/algunas-curiosidades-sobre-el-siempre-recordado-gustavo-cerati/|archivedate=28 January 2018|df=}}</ref> * [[Coco Chanel]]<ref>{{cite web|last=Samuel|first=Henry|title=Whiff of Kafka to Coco Chanel smoking poster ban|url=http://blogs.telegraph.co.uk/news/henrysamuel/9597429/Whiff_of_Kafka_to_Coco_Chanel_smoking_poster_ban/|work=telegraph.co.uk|access-date=27 October 2013|date=22 April 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140116083922/http://blogs.telegraph.co.uk/news/henrysamuel/9597429/Whiff_of_Kafka_to_Coco_Chanel_smoking_poster_ban/|archivedate=16 January 2014|df=}}</ref> * [[John Daly (golfer)|John Daly]]<ref name="espn">{{cite web|last=Lukas|first=Paul|title=The rule in sports: Smoke 'em if you got 'em|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/page2/story?page=lukas/080424|work=ESPN.com|access-date=27 October 2013|date=29 April 2008|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029213012/http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/page2/story?page=lukas%2F080424|archivedate=29 October 2013|df=}}</ref> * [[Bette Davis]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rogerebert.com/scanners/bette-davis-at-104-still-smokin|title=BETTE DAVIS AT 104: STILL SMOKIN'|date=7 April 2012|access-date=9 September 2018|df=}}</ref> * [[Lana Del Rey]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.complex.com/covers/lana-del-rey-interview-against-the-grain-2014-cover-story/|work=Complex|title=Against the Grain|author=Droppo, Dana|date=August 2014|access-date=20 August 2015|quote=There's a grace to the way she chain-smokes Parliaments and says "fuck" when she chips one of her pointed purple acrylic nails.}}</ref> * [[King Diamond]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/king-diamond-undergoes-triple-bypass-heart-surgery |title=King Diamond Undergoes Triple Bypass Heart Surgery |work=Blabbermouth.net |date=11 December 2010 |access-date=14 December 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141222191356/http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/king-diamond-undergoes-triple-bypass-heart-surgery/ |archivedate=22 December 2014 |df= }}</ref> * [[Joe DiMaggio]]<ref>{{cite news|last=Jerome|first=Richard|title=Joe Dimaggio: the Quiet Man|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20127805,00.html|access-date=27 October 2013|newspaper=People {{Infobox medical condition (new) | name = <!--{{PAGENAME}} by default--> | synonym = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | pronounce = | specialty = <!-- from Wikidata, can be overwritten --> | symptoms = | complications = | onset = | duration = | types = | causes = | risks = | diagnosis = | differential = | prevention = | treatment = | medication = | prognosis = | frequency = | deaths = }} '''Constipation in children''' refers to the medical condition of [[constipation]] in children. It is a [[functional gastrointestinal disorder]].
==Characteristics== Children have different bowel movement patterns than adults. In addition, there is a wide spectrum of normalcy when considering children’s bowel habits.<ref name=Col2015 /> On average, infants have 3-4 bowel movements/day, and toddlers have 2-3 bowel movements per day. At around age 4, children develop an adult-like pattern of bowel movements (1-2 stools/day). Children benefit from scheduled toilet breaks, once early in the morning and 30 minutes after meals.<ref name=walia>{{cite journal |vauthors=Walia R, Mahajan L, Steffen R | title = Recent advances in chronic constipation | journal = Curr Opin Pediatr | volume = 21 | issue = 5 | pages = 661–6 | date = October 2009 | pmid = 19606041 | doi = 10.1097/MOP.0b013e32832ff241 }}</ref><ref name=bharucha>{{cite journal | author = Bharucha AE | title = Constipation | journal = Best Practice & Research Clinical Gastroenterology | volume = 21 | issue = 4 | pages = 709–31 | year = 2007 | pmid = 17643910 | doi = 10.1016/j.bpg.2007.07.001 }}</ref> The Rome III Criteria for constipation in children helps to define constipation for various age groups.
==Causes==
While it is difficult to assess an exact age at which constipation most commonly arises, children frequently suffer from constipation in conjunction with life-changes. Examples include: toilet training, starting or transferring to a new school, and changes in diet.<ref name=Col2015 /> Especially in infants, changes in formula or transitioning from breast milk to formula can cause constipation. Fortunately, the majority of constipation cases are not tied to a medical disease, and treatment can be focused on simply relieving the symptoms.<ref name=":1" />
=== Congenital causes=== [[Congenital disorder|A number of diseases present at birth]] can result in constipation. They are as a group uncommon with Hirschsprung’s disease (HD) being the most common.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Constipation: etiology, evaluation and management|last=Wexner|first=Steven|publisher=Springer|year=2006|isbn=|location=New York|pages=}}</ref> HD is more common in males than females, affecting 1 out of 5000 babies. In people with HD, specific types of cells called ‘neural crest cells’ fail to migrate to parts of the colon. This causes the affected portion of the colon to be unable to contract and relax to help push out a bowel movement. The affected portion of the colon remains contracted, making it difficult for stool to pass through.<ref name="Wesson">{{Cite web|url=https://www.uptodate.com/contents/congenital-aganglionic-megacolon-hirschsprung-disease?source=search_result&search=hirschsprung%20disease%20children&selectedTitle=1~69|title=UpToDate: Constipation|last=Wesson|first=David|date=November 9, 2016|website=UpToDate|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=March 15, 2017}}</ref> Concern for HD should be raised in a child who has not passed stool during the first 48 hours of life. Milder forms of HD, in which only a small portion of the colon is affected, can present later in childhood as constipation, abdominal pain, and bloating.<ref name="Wesson"/> Similar disorders to HD include anal [[achalasia]] and hypoganglionosis. In hypoganglionosis, there is a low number of neural crest cells, so the colon remains contracted. In anal achalasia, the internal anal sphincter remains contracted, making it difficult for stool to pass. However, there is a normal number of neural crest cells present.<ref name=":1" />
There are also congenital structural anomalies that can lead to constipation, including anterior displacement of the anus, [[imperforate anus]], strictures, and small left colon syndrome.<ref name=":1" /> Anterior displacement of the anus can be diagnosed on physical exam.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Pediatrics|first=American Academy of|date=1986-08-01|title=Congenital Anterior Displacement of Anus|url=http://pedsinreview.aappublications.org/content/8/2/38|journal=Pediatrics in Review|language=en|volume=8|issue=2|pages=38–62|doi=10.1542/pir.8-2-38|issn=0191-9601}}</ref> The disease causes constipation because the inappropriate positioning of the anus which make it difficult to pass a bowel movement. Imperforate anus is an anus that ends in a blind pouch and does not connect to the rest of the person's intestines. Small left colon syndrome is a rare disease in which the left side of the babies colon has a small diameter, which makes it difficult for stool to pass. A risk factor for small left colon syndrome is having a mother with diabetes.<ref name=":1" />
Some symptoms that may indicate an underlying disease include:<ref name=Col2015>{{Cite journal|last=Colombo|first=Jennifer M.|last2=Wassom|first2=Matthew C.|last3=Rosen|first3=John M.|date=2015-09-01|title=Constipation and Encopresis in Childhood|journal=Pediatrics in Review|volume=36|issue=9|pages=392–401; quiz 402|doi=10.1542/pir.36-9-392|issn=1526-3347|pmid=26330473}}</ref> * Bowel movements that contain blood. * Severe abdominal bloating. * Peri-[[anal fistula]] * Absent [[anal wink]] reflex * [[Sacral dimple]] * [[Failure to thrive]]
==Diagnosis== [[File:Main measuring sites of colon diameter.jpg|thumb|The diameters of different segments of the large intestine can be compared to the width of [[lumbar vertebra 2]] for more consistent reference ranges on [[abdominal x-ray]]s.<ref name=Koppen2016>{{cite journal|last1=Koppen|first1=Ilan J. N.|last2=Yacob|first2=Desale|last3=Di Lorenzo|first3=Carlo|last4=Saps|first4=Miguel|last5=Benninga|first5=Marc A.|last6=Cooper|first6=Jennifer N.|last7=Minneci|first7=Peter C.|last8=Deans|first8=Katherine J.|last9=Bates|first9=D. Gregory|last10=Thompson|first10=Benjamin P.|title=Assessing colonic anatomy normal values based on air contrast enemas in children younger than 6 years|journal=Pediatric Radiology|volume=47|issue=3|year=2016|pages=306–312|issn=0301-0449|doi=10.1007/s00247-016-3746-0|url=http://europepmc.org/articles/PMC5316394;jsessionid=2F0B0FCBD478428D0B64AA24476321EE}}</ref>]] [[File:Ratios of large intestinal segments compared to lumbar vertebra 2.png|thumb|Ratios of large intestinal segments compared to lumbar vertebra 2, as 75th [[percentile]], meaning that 25% of children normally have a ratio higher than this.<ref name=Koppen2016/>]] The [[Rome process]] suggests a diagnosis of constipation in children fewer than 4 years old when the child has 2 or more of the following complaints for at least 1 month.<ref name=":1" /> For children older than 4 years, there must be 2 of these complaints for at least 2 months. * 2 or fewer bowel movements per week * Passing large bowel movements * On physical exam, a doctor may find large amounts of feces within the child’s rectum. * A child who is already toilet trained has at least 1 accident per week involving a bowel movement. * Child demonstrates withholding behavior in which he or she actively tries not to pass a bowel movement. * Hard stools * Pain with defecation.
For children, the degree of constipation may be scored by the ''Leech'' or the ''Barr'' systems: [[File:Leech scoring areas.jpg|thumb|Areas used for the Leech system of constipation grading.]] *The Leech system assigns a score of 0 to 5 based on the amount of feces:<ref name="LeechMcHugh1999">{{cite journal|last1=Leech|first1=Susan C.|last2=McHugh|first2=Kieran|last3=Sullivan|first3=P. B.|title=Evaluation of a method of assessing faecal loading on plain abdominal radiographs in children|journal=Pediatric Radiology|volume=29|issue=4|year=1999|pages=255–258|issn=0301-0449|doi=10.1007/s002470050583}}</ref> :*0: no visible feces :*1: scanty feces visible :*2: mild fecal loading :*3: moderate fecal loading :*4: severe fecal loading :*5: severe fecal loading with bowel dilatation :These score are assigned separately for the right colon, the left colon and the rectosigmoid colon, resulting in a maximum score of 15. A Leech score of 9 or greater is regarded as positive for constipation.<ref name="LeechMcHugh1999"/> *The Barr system rates both the amount and consistency of the faeces, and assigns a score separately for the ascending colon, transverse colon, descending colon and rectum. Its maximum score is 22, and a score of 10 or greater is regarded as positive for constipation.<ref name="G.H.2012">{{cite journal|last1=G.|first1=Anthony|last2=H.|first2=Kathleen|title=The Role of Diagnostic Tests in Constipation in Children|journal=|year=2012|doi=10.5772/29213}}</ref>
==Treatment== [[Lactulose]] and milk of magnesia have been compared with [[polyethylene glycol]] (PEG) in children. All had similar side effects, but PEG was more effective at treating constipation.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bestbets.org/bets/bet.php?id=1471 |title=Is PEG (Polyethylene Glycol) a more effective laxative than Lactulose in the treatment of a child who is constipated? |work = BestBETs |date = 16 July 2007 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Candy D, Belsey J | title = Macrogol (polyethylene glycol) laxatives in children with functional constipation and faecal impaction: a systematic review | journal = Arch. Dis. Child. | volume = 94 | issue = 2 | pages = 156–60 | date = February 2009 | pmid = 19019885 | pmc = 2614562 | doi = 10.1136/adc.2007.128769 }}</ref> Osmotic laxatives are recommended over stimulant laxatives.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bestbets.org/bets/bet.php?id=1478 |title= Osmotic laxative are preferable to the use of stimulant laxatives in the constipated child | work = BestBETs | date = 9 November 2007}}</ref>
==Epidemiology== There is wide variation in the rates of constipation as reported by research in various countries.<ref name="Boronat 2017">{{cite journal|last1=Boronat|first1=Alexandre Canon|last2=Ferreira-Maia|first2=Ana Paula|last3=Matijasevich|first3=Alicia|last4=Wang|first4=Yuan-Pang|title=Epidemiology of functional gastrointestinal disorders in children and adolescents: A systematic review|journal=World Journal of Gastroenterology|date=2017|volume=23|issue=21|pages=3915|doi=10.3748/wjg.v23.i21.3915}}</ref> The variation in research data makes it challenging to describe the true global situation.<ref name="Boronat 2017"/>
Approximately 3% of children have constipation, with girls and boys being equally affected.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Tabbers|first=M.M.|last2=DiLorenzo|first2=C.|last3=Berger|first3=M.Y.|last4=Faure|first4=C.|last5=Langendam|first5=M.W.|last6=Nurko|first6=S.|last7=Staiano|first7=A.|last8=Vandenplas|first8=Y.|last9=Benninga|first9=M.A.|title=Evaluation and Treatment of Functional Constipation in Infants and Children|url=http://content.wkhealth.com/linkback/openurl?sid=WKPTLP:landingpage&an=00005176-201402000-00027|journal=Journal of Pediatric Gastroenterology and Nutrition|volume=58|issue=2|pages=265–281|doi=10.1097/mpg.0000000000000266}}</ref> With constipation accounting for approximately 5% of general pediatrician visits and 25% of pediatric gastroenterologist visits, the symptom carries a significant financial impact upon our healthcare system.<ref name=Col2015/>
==Society and culture== Constipation is often emotionally stressful for children and their caregivers.<ref name="Ferrara 2017">{{cite journal|last1=Ferrara|first1=Lucille R.|last2=Saccomano|first2=Scott J.|title=Constipation in children|journal=The Nurse Practitioner|date=July 2017|volume=42|issue=7|pages=30–34|doi=10.1097/01.NPR.0000520418.32331.6e}}</ref> It is common for parents to bring their children to doctors for this condition.<ref name="Ferrara 2017"/> The experience of going to a doctor for this can be stressful.<ref name="Ferrara 2017"/>
Too often, children at doctors receive [[unnecessary health care]] when they get [[medical imaging]] for constipation.<ref name="Ferguson 2017">{{cite journal|last1=Ferguson|first1=Catherine Craun|last2=Gray|first2=Matthew P.|last3=Diaz|first3=Melissa|last4=Boyd|first4=Kevin P.|title=Reducing Unnecessary Imaging for Patients With Constipation in the Pediatric Emergency Department|journal=Pediatrics|date=July 2017|volume=140|issue=1|pages=e20162290|doi=10.1542/peds.2016-2290}}</ref> Children should only get tests when there is an [[indication (medicine)|indication]].<ref name="Ferguson 2017"/>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *"[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SgBj7Mc_4sc The Poo in You]" - Children's Hospital Colorado presents a 6-minute video for children about constipation
[[Category:Constipation]] [[Category:Pediatrics]]

revision.text:
'''Cream skimming''' is a [[pejorative]] [[conceptual metaphor]] used to refer to the perceived business practice of a company providing a product or a service to only the high-value or low-cost customers of that product or service, while disregarding clients that are less profitable for the company.
[[File:Separator, Klosters bruksmuseum.jpg|thumb|150px|right|A cream separator, which uses manual [[centrifugal force]] to separate cream from milk.]] The term derives from the practice of extracting [[cream]] from fresh milk at a [[dairy]], in which a [[separator (milk)|separator]] draws off the cream (which is lighter, and floats) from fresh or raw milk. The cream has now been "skimmed" or captured separately from the fresh milk.
The idea behind the concept of cream skimming in business is that the "cream" – high value or low-cost customers, who are more profitable to serve – would be captured by some suppliers (typically by charging less than the previous higher prices, but still making a profit), leaving the more expensive or harder to service customers without the desired product or service at all or "dumping" them on some default provider, who is left with less of the higher value customers who, in some cases, would have provided extra revenue to subsidize or reduce the cost to service the higher-cost customers, and the loss of the higher value customers might actually require the default provider to have to ''raise'' prices to cover the lost revenue, thus making things worse.
Whether or not the perceived negative effects of cream skimming actually do occur – or only occur in limited circumstances – is a matter of judgment and debate.
==Examples== The term has been used in relation to the concept of [[school vouchers]] in which it is claimed that the vouchers could be used by parents of "better" students (i.e., students with above average grades who are not disciplinary risks) to move them out of lower performing or substandard [[state school]]s and into less-crowded [[private school|private]] ones, leaving the "worse" students (i.e., students with learning disabilities or who are troublemakers) behind in the state schools, making the situation worse.
For example, it was believed that [[MCI Communications|MCI]] and [[Sprint Nextel|Sprint]] [[Interexchange carrier|long distance telephone]] companies would end up taking away very high value business and some residential accounts from [[AT&T]], leaving AT&T primarily with higher-cost to service accounts or ones producing less revenue (such as customers in less-densely populated or rural areas), meaning all customers of AT&T would end up paying more.<ref>An example of how it is believed competitors may take advantage of cream skimming off the carrier of last resort in telecommunications, who otherwise would be making monopoly profits, is given by Peter Smith, "Subscribing to Monopoly" in ''Public Policy for the Private Sector'', [[The World Bank]], September, 1995, available at {{cite web |url=http://rru.worldbank.org/documents/publicpolicyjournal/053smith.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-03-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070618060635/http://rru.worldbank.org/Documents/PublicPolicyJournal/053smith.pdf |archivedate=2007-06-18 |df= }}, (179K, retrieved March 11, 2008)</ref> This could conceivably lead to a [[vicious circle]] as more customers leave the high-price carrier for the lower priced carrier, thus forcing still more price increases to cover the upward spiraling costs of providing service to a shrinking revenue base. This scenario did not occur, as various technological changes (spurred in part by the availability of competition) eventually lowered the net cost for most long-distance telephone calls.<ref>Examples of how extreme competition in telephone service drove prices down and cream skimming did not occur are given in Martin Ostermayer, Christian Nobs and Darrell Gualco, ''Business: Local Service Market including ILEC and CLEC'', 17 February 1999 at {{cite web |url=http://www.ehrlichorg.com/s99ibm/b0217-02.doc |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-03-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041227070412/http://www.ehrlichorg.com/s99ibm/b0217-02.doc |archivedate=2004-12-27 |df= }} (Microsoft Word Document, 172K, retrieved 11 March 2008)</ref>
The [[United States Postal Service]] has a monopoly on the delivery of "non-urgent" first-class mail, where delivery is not time-sensitive. It also has the exclusive right to use customer-owned mail boxes for placing the customer's mail for delivery. This means that, even though mail boxes, such as those in the door of a house, or on the curb, or in the front lobby of the customer's building, are owned by the customer, and not owned by the Postal Service, by law only the Postal Service may use them to deliver mail. This law is in effect because it is believed that were the Postal Service to not have this monopoly, other competing mail carriers would take over the most lucrative parts of the business (e.g. local delivery of bills in dense urban areas), leaving the Postal Service with more expensive urban deliveries and rural service.<ref>An analysis of this particular factor is given in Michael A. Crew and Paul R. Kleindorfer ''Emerging Competition in Postal and Delivery Services'', in Chapter 10, "An Analysis of the Potential of Cream Skimming in the United States Residential Delivery Market" by Robert H. Cohen, William W. Ferguson, John D. Walker and Spyros X. Xenakis. A sample from this chapter is available from Google Book Search at [https://books.google.com/books?id=4nd-sU4jOE8C&pg=PA141&lpg=PA141&dq=postal+mail+%22cream+skimming%22&source=web&ots=ZzMCSiAaay&sig=_bjE4OAqVtUMcekStnVwmHmyeHU&hl=en this link] (Retrieved 11 March 2008) The same article also appears as a web page on the website of the [[Postal Regulatory Commission]] at http://www.prc.gov/prc-docs/library/refdesk/techpapers/prcstaff/cohen.pdf{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} (Retrieved 14 April 2011)</ref>
==See also== * [[Redlining]]
==References== <references />
[[Category:Economic inequality]] [[Category:Ethically disputed business practices]] [[Category:Pejoratives]] [[Category:Metaphors referring to food and drink]] [[Category:Economics catchphrases]]

{{Expand Spanish|Protésico dental|topic=sci|date=December 2009}} [[File:VMK-Krone2.jpg| thumb | 250px | Dental technologist building porcelain [[dental bridge]].]]
A '''dental technologist''' (dental laboratory technician) is a member of the dental team who, upon prescription from a dental clinician, constructs custom-made restorative and dental appliances.<ref>[http://www.dentalcouncil.org.nz/Documents/Scopes/ScopesOfPractice_Technicians.pdf Dental Council of New Zealand, ''Notice of Scopes of Practice and Prescribed Qualifications'']</ref><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20101122105433/http://www.gdc-uk.org/NR/rdonlyres/6E573762-BD24-418C-A863-7283A05E6A9F/0/ScopeofpracticeApril2009.pdf General Dental Council UK, ''Scopes of Practice'']</ref>
There are four major disciplines within dental technology. These are ''fixed prosthesis'' including [[Crown (dentistry)|crowns]], [[bridge (dentistry)|bridges]] and [[Dental implant|implants]]; ''removable prosthesis'', including [[dentures]] and [[removable partial denture]]s; ''maxillofacial prosthesis'', including [[ocular prosthesis]] and [[craniofacial prosthesis]]; and ''orthodontics and auxiliaries'', including [[orthodontic technology|orthodontic appliances]] and [[mouthguard]]s.<ref>[http://www.nhscareers.nhs.uk/details/Default.aspx?Id=142 ''Dental technician/dental technologist'' NHS Careers]</ref>
The dentist communicates with the dental technologist with prescriptions, drawings and measurements taken from the patient. The most important aspect of this is a [[Impression (dental)|dental impression]] into which the technologist flows a [[Plaster#In medicine|gypsum dental stone]] to create a replica of the patient's anatomy known as a dental cast. A technologist can then use this cast for the construction of custom appliances.<ref>[http://www.tpub.com/content/medical/14275/css/14275_203.htm ''Fabricating Casts'' http://www.tpub.com/content/medical/14275/css/14275_203.htm]</ref>
==Fixed restorations== A '''fixed dental restoration''' is an appliance designed to replace a tooth or teeth that may have been lost or damaged by injury, caries or other oral diseases. These restorations are distinguished from other restorations by the fact that once they have been placed by a dentist the patient can not remove them.<ref>[https://www.scribd.com/doc/6630184/The-Functionally-Fixed-Restoration ''The functional fixed'' https://www.scribd.com/doc/6630184/The-Functionally-Fixed-Restoration]</ref> Such Restorations include; crowns, bridges, veneers, fixed implant restorations, inlays and onlays.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Zitzmann |first1=Nicola Ursula |last2=Hagmann |first2=Edgar |last3=Weiger |first3=Roland |title=What is the prevalence of various types of prosthetic dental restorations in Europe? |journal=Clinical Oral Implants Research |volume=18 |pages=20–33 |year=2007 |pmid=17594367 |doi=10.1111/j.1600-0501.2007.01435.x}}</ref><ref>[http://www.mercurypoisoned.com/different.html ''Types of Dental Restorations'' http://www.mercurypoisoned.com/different.html]</ref>
==Removable restorations== '''Removable restorations''' are dental appliances to replace one or more teeth that have been completely lost. These restorations ideally remain stable in normal function but can be removed by the patient for cleaning and at night. Removable restorations are either retained by the patients soft tissue as in full dentures,<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/0022-3913(83)90228-7 |last1=Jacobson |first1=TE |last2=Krol |first2=AJ |title=A contemporary review of the factors involved in complete denture retention, stability, and support. Part I: retention |journal=The Journal of prosthetic dentistry |volume=49 |issue=1 |pages=5–15 |year=1983 |pmid=6337253}}</ref> supported by other teeth as with partial dentures and [[overdenture]]s<ref>[http://homepages.nyu.edu/~gsb5/RPD_step_by_step_protocol.pdf ''Removable partial denture design protocol'']</ref> or on implant attachments as with implant retained overdentures and partial dentures.
==Orthodontics== Orthodontic technologists make removable orthodontic appliances with wires, springs and screws on prescription from an [[orthodontist]] to either move teeth to form a more harmonious occlusion and aesthetic appearance of teeth or to maintain the position of previously moved teeth.
==See also== * [[Dentistry]] * [[Dental auxiliary]] ** [[Dental assistant]] ** [[Dental therapist]] ** [[Dental hygienist]] * [[Denturist]] * [[Orthodontic Technicians Association]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.dta-uk.org/ Dental Technologists' Association]
{{Authority control}} [[Category:Dentistry branches]] [[Category:Technicians]]

'''Diplophonia,''' also known as diphthongia, is a phenomenon in which a voice is perceived as being produced with two concurrent pitches.<ref>{{Cite journal|last = Ward|last2 = Sanders|last3 = Goldman|last4 = Moore|year = 1969|title = Diplophonia|journal = The Annals of Otology, Rhinology, and Laryngology|volume = 78}}</ref> Diplophonia is a result of vocal fold vibrations that are quasi-periodic in nature.<ref>{{Cite journal|last = Kiritani|last2 = Hirose|last3 = Imagawa|year = 1993|title = High-speed digital image analysis of vocal cord vibration in diplophonia|journal = Speech Communication|volume = 13}}</ref> It has been reported from old days, but there are no uniform interpretation of established mechanisms.<ref name="Yoshioka 1987">{{Cite web|url=https://tsukuba.repo.nii.ac.jp/?action=repository_uri&item_id=1393&file_id=17&file_no=1|title=二重声の成立機序に関する音響的側面について|author=吉岡博英|publisher=筑波大学|accessdate=2015-12-26|date=1987|language=Japanese}}</ref> It has been established that diplophonia can be caused by various vocal fold pathologies, such as [[vocal folds]] [[polyp (medicine)|polyp]], [[vocal fold nodule]], [[recurrent laryngeal nerve]] paralysis<ref name="Yoshioka 1987" /> or [[vestibular fold]] hypertrophy.<ref name="sickness-dictionary">{{Cite web|url=http://www.sickness-dictionary.jp/nosethroat/karisetaihidai.html|publisher=sickness-dictionary.jp|title=仮声帯肥大|accessdate=2015-12-26|language=Japanese}}</ref>
==References== <references/>

revision.text:
{{Infobox medical intervention | name = Endoscopic sleeve gastroplasty | synonym = | image = | caption = | alt = | pronounce = | specialty = [[Gastroenterology]], [[Bariatrics]] | synonyms = | ICD10 = | ICD9 = | ICD9unlinked = | CPT = | MeshID = | LOINC = | other_codes = | MedlinePlus = | eMedicine = }}
'''Endoscopic sleeve gastroplasty''' is a form of [[minimally invasive]] [[Endoscopy|endoscopic]] [[gastroplasty]], in which [[Surgical suture|sutures]] are made within the stomach using an [[endoscope]] inserted through the mouth into the stomach.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Sharaiha |first1=Reem |title=Managing Obesity With Endoscopic Sleeve Gastroplasty |journal=Gastroenterology & Hepatology |volume=13 |issue=9 |pages=547–549 |issn=1554-7914|pmc=5635430 |year=2017 |pmid=29038645 }}</ref>
It is regarded as an alternative to more invasive forms of [[bariatric surgery]].<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Sharaiha |first1=Reem Z. |last2=Kumta |first2=Nikhil A. |last3=Saumoy |first3=Monica |last4=Desai |first4=Amit P. |last5=Sarkisian |first5=Alex M. |last6=Benevenuto |first6=Andrea |last7=Tyberg |first7=Amy |last8=Kumar |first8=Rekha |last9=Igel |first9=Leon |last10=Verna |first10=Elizabeth C. |last11=Schwartz |first11=Robert |last12=Frissora |first12=Christina |last13=Shukla |first13=Alpana |last14=Aronne |first14=Louis J. |last15=Kahaleh |first15=Michel |title=Endoscopic Sleeve Gastroplasty Significantly Reduces Body Mass Index and Metabolic Complications in Obese Patients |journal=Clinical Gastroenterology and Hepatology: The Official Clinical Practice Journal of the American Gastroenterological Association |volume=15 |issue=4 |pages=504–510 |doi=10.1016/j.cgh.2016.12.012 |pmid=28017845 |issn=1542-7714|year=2017 }}</ref> It is believed to work through inducing changes in gastric physiology.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Abu Dayyeh |first1=Barham K. |last2=Acosta |first2=Andres |last3=Camilleri |first3=Michael |last4=Mundi |first4=Manpreet S. |last5=Rajan |first5=Elizabeth |last6=Topazian |first6=Mark D. |last7=Gostout |first7=Christopher J. |title=Endoscopic Sleeve Gastroplasty Alters Gastric Physiology and Induces Loss of Body Weight in Obese Individuals |journal=Clinical Gastroenterology and Hepatology: The Official Clinical Practice Journal of the American Gastroenterological Association |volume=15 |issue=1 |pages=37–43.e1 |doi=10.1016/j.cgh.2015.12.030 |pmid=26748219 |issn=1542-7714|year=2017 }}</ref>
== See also ==
* [[Vertical banded gastroplasty surgery]] == References == {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== *{{cite journal |last1=Jain |first1=Deepanshu |last2=Bhandari |first2=Bharat Singh |last3=Arora |first3=Ankit |last4=Singhal |first4=Shashideep |title=Endoscopic Sleeve Gastroplasty - A New Tool to Manage Obesity |journal=Clinical Endoscopy |date=November 2017 |volume=50 |issue=6 |pages=552–561 |doi=10.5946/ce.2017.032 |pmid=28607328 |pmc=5719914 |issn=2234-2400}}(Review) *{{cite journal |last1=Badurdeen |first1=Dilhana S. |last2=Kumbhari |first2=Vivek |title=Endoscopic sleeve gastroplasty and its application to China |journal=Journal of Digestive Diseases |date=October 2017 |volume=18 |issue=10 |pages=551–555 |doi=10.1111/1751-2980.12547 |pmid=28960917 |issn=1751-2980}}(Review)

{{medref|date=October 2012}} {{Infobox interventions | Name = Gynecologic ultrasonography | Image = Hydrosalpinx (left).jpg | Caption = Left [[hydrosalpinx]] on gyn. ultrasonography | ICD10 = | ICD9 = {{ICD9proc|88.76}}, {{ICD9proc|88.79}} | MeshID = | OPS301 = {{OPS301|3-05d}} | OtherCodes = | }} '''Gynecologic ultrasonography''' or '''gynecologic sonography''' refers to the application of [[medical ultrasonography]] to the female pelvic organs (specifically the [[uterus]], the [[ovaries]], and the [[Fallopian tubes]]) as well as the [[Urinary bladder|bladder]], the [[Adnexa of uterus|adnexa]], and the [[Pouch of Douglas]]. The procedure may lead to other medically relevant findings in the pelvis.
==Routes== [[File:Transvaginal ultrasonography device.png|thumb|Device for both [[vaginal ultrasonography]] and [[abdominal ultrasonography]].]] [[File:Mirena in optimal place - schematic.png|thumb|[[Transvaginal ultrasonography]] to check the location of an [[intrauterine device]] (IUD).]]
The examination can be performed by [[transabdominal ultrasonography]], generally with a full bladder which acts as an [[acoustic window]] to achieve better visualization of pelvis organs, or by [[transvaginal ultrasonography]] with a specifically designed vaginal transducer. Transvaginal imaging utilizes a higher frequency imaging, which gives better resolution of the ovaries, uterus and [[endometrium]] (the fallopian tubes are generally not seen unless distended), but is limited to depth of image penetration, whereas larger lesions reaching into the abdomen are better seen transabdominally. Having a full bladder for the transabdominal portion of the exam is helpful because sound travels through fluid with less attenuation to better visualize the uterus and ovaries which lies posteriorly to the bladder. The procedure is by definition [[Invasiveness of surgical procedures|invasive]] when performed transvaginally. Scans are performed by health care professionals called sonographers, or gynecologists trained in ultrasound.
==Applications== Gynecologic sonography is used extensively: * to assess pelvic organs, * to diagnose [[acute appendicitis]]<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Caspi | first1 = B. | last2 = Zbar | first2 = AP. | last3 = Mavor | first3 = E. | last4 = Hagay | first4 = Z. | last5 = Appelman | first5 = Z. | title = The contribution of transvaginal ultrasound in the diagnosis of acute appendicitis: an observational study. | journal = Ultrasound Obstet Gynecol | volume = 21 | issue = 3 | pages = 273–6 |date=Mar 2003 | doi = 10.1002/uog.72 | PMID = 12666223 }}</ref> * to diagnose and manage gynecologic problems including [[endometriosis]], [[leiomyoma]], [[adenomyosis]], ovarian cysts and lesions, * to identify adnexal masses, including [[ectopic pregnancy]], * to diagnose gynecologic [[cancer]] * in infertility treatments to track the response of [[ovarian follicle]]s to [[fertility medication]] (i.e. [[Pergonal]]). However, it often underestimates the true ovarian volume.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Rosendahl M, Ernst E, Rasmussen PE, Yding Andersen C |title=True ovarian volume is underestimated by two-dimensional transvaginal ultrasound measurement |journal=Fertil. Steril. |volume= 93|issue= 3|pages= 995–998|date=December 2008 |pmid=19108822 |doi=10.1016/j.fertnstert.2008.10.055 |url=}}</ref>
Through transvaginal sonography ovarian cysts can be aspirated. This technique is also used in [[transvaginal oocyte retrieval]] to obtain human eggs ([[oocyte]]s) through sonographic directed transvaginal puncture of ovarian follicles in [[IVF]].
Gynecologic ultrasonography is sometimes [[unnecessary health care|overused]] when it is used to screen for ovarian cancer in women who are not at risk for this cancer.<ref name="ACOGfive">{{Citation |author1 = American Congress of Obstetricians and Gynecologists |author1-link = American Congress of Obstetricians and Gynecologists |date = |title = Five Things Physicians and Patients Should Question |publisher = [[American Congress of Obstetricians and Gynecologists]] |work = [[Choosing Wisely]]: an initiative of the [[ABIM Foundation]] |page = |url = http://www.choosingwisely.org/doctor-patient-lists/american-college-of-obstetricians-and-gynecologists/ |accessdate = August 1, 2013}}, which cites *{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1370/afm.200 | title = Screening for Ovarian Cancer: Recommendation Statement | journal = The Annals of Family Medicine | volume = 2 | issue = 3 | pages = 260–262 | year = 2004 | pmid = | pmc = }} *{{citation |last1=Lin |first1=Kenneth |last2=Barton |first2=Mary B. |title=Screening for Ovarian Cancer - Evidence Update for the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force Reaffirmation Recommendation Statement |url=http://www.uspreventiveservicestaskforce.org/uspstf12/ovarian/ovarart.htm |work=AHRQ Publication No. 12-05165-EF-3 |publisher=United States Preventive Services Task Force |accessdate=30 August 2013 |date=April 2012}} *{{Cite journal | last1 = Partridge | first1 = E. | last2 = Greenlee | first2 = A. R. | last3 = Xu | first3 = R. T. | last4 = Kreimer | first4 = C. | last5 = Williams | first5 = J. L. | last6 = Riley | first6 = T. R. | last7 = Reding | first7 = B. | last8 = Church | first8 = C. C. | last9 = Kessel | first9 = J. L. | last10 = Johnson | first10 = C. | last11 = Hill | first11 = G. L. | last12 = Fouad | first12 = S. | last13 = Buys | first13 = L. R. | last14 = Isaacs | first14 = S. S. | last15 = Andriole | first15 = T. | last16 = Ogden | first16 = S. | last17 = Chia | first17 = D. | last18 = Ragard | first18 = L. R. | last19 = Prorok | first19 = P. C. | last20 = Gohagan | first20 = J. K. | last21 = Berg | first21 = C. D. | title = Results from four rounds of ovarian cancer screening in a randomized trial | journal = Obstetrics and gynecology | volume = 113 | issue = 4 | pages = 775–782 | doi = 10.1097/AOG.0b013e31819cda77 | year = 2009 | pmid = 19305319 | pmc =2728067 }} *{{Cite journal | author1=American College of Obstetricians| author2=Gynecologists Committee on Gynecologic Practice| doi = 10.1097/AOG.0b013e31821477db | title = Committee Opinion No. 477: The Role of the Obstetrician–Gynecologist in the Early Detection of Epithelial Ovarian Cancer | journal = Obstetrics & Gynecology | volume = 117 | issue = 3 | pages = 742–746 | year = 2011 | pmid = 21343791 | pmc = }}</ref> There is consensus that women with only average risk for ovarian cancer should not be screened with this procedure for cancer.<ref name="ACOGfive"/>
==Sonohysterography== [[Image:Normal hysterosonography.png|thumb|Sonohysterography. The sterile saline instilled into the cavity of the uterus is [[anechoic]] (rendered as dark in the middle of the image). It shows a normal endometrium as a hyperechoid (brighter) band around the cavity, in this case without any focal changes.]] '''Sonohysterography''' is a specialized procedure by which fluid, usually sterile saline (then called '''saline infusion sonography''' or '''SIS'''), is instilled into the uterine cavity, and gynecologic sonography performed at the same time. A review in 2015 came to the conclusion that SIS is highly [[sensitivity and specificity|sensitive]] in the detection of intrauterine abnormalities in [[subfertile women]], comparable to [[hysteroscopy]]. SIS is highly sensitive and [[sensitivity and specificity|specific]] test in the diagnosis of [[uterine polyp]]s, submucous [[uterine fibroid]]s, [[uterine anomalies]] and [[intrauterine adhesions]] (as part of [[Asherman's syndrome]]), and can be used as a screening tool for subfertile women prior to [[in vitro fertilisation|IVF]] treatment.<ref name="SeshadriEl-Toukhy2014">{{cite journal|last1=Seshadri|first1=S.|last2=El-Toukhy|first2=T.|last3=Douiri|first3=A.|last4=Jayaprakasan|first4=K.|last5=Khalaf|first5=Y.|title=Diagnostic accuracy of saline infusion sonography in the evaluation of uterine cavity abnormalities prior to assisted reproductive techniques: a systematic review and meta-analyses|journal=Human Reproduction Update|volume=21|issue=2|year=2014|pages=262–274|issn=1355-4786|doi=10.1093/humupd/dmu057|pmid=25505226}}</ref>
[[File:Sonohysterography 14380514444700921.jpg|thumb|Sonohysterography using a balloon catheter (seen in the middle of the image.]]
==See also== * [[Gynography]] * [[Gynoroentgenology]] * [[Obstetric ultrasonography]] * [[Sonosalpingography]] * [[Vaginal ultrasonography]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.radiologyinfo.org/content/ultrasound-pelvis.htm Information about Sonography]
